data.title: Prediction of the stability of the ${M}_{n+1}A{X}_{n}$ phases from first principles
data.meta_description: One of the unusual features of the ${M}_{n+1}A{X}_{n}$ phases (where $M$ is a transition metal, $A$ is a group A element, $X$ is carbon or nitrogen, and $n=1,2,3\dots{}$) is that for a given $M\text{\ensuremath{-}}A\text{\ensuremath{-}}X$ system, only certain values of $n$ are found to occur and there is no systematic behavior between the different systems. Density-functional theory was used to verify the stability of the different phases by comparing their total energy to that of the appropriate competing phases. Five systems (Ti-Al-C, Ti-Si-C, Ti-Al-N, Ti-Si-N, and Cr-Al-C) were studied for $n=1--4$. Complete agreement with observed occurrences of these phases was found. Very small energy differences suggest that it may be possible to fabricate ${\text{Ti}}_{2}\text{SiC}$, ${\text{Ti}}_{2}\text{SiN}$, and ${\text{Ti}}_{3}{\text{AlN}}_{2}$ as metastable phases. None of the ${M}_{5}A{X}_{4}$ phases were predicted to occur and in all cases the $\ensuremath{\alpha}$ phases were found to be more energetically favorable than the $\ensuremath{\beta}$ phases.
data.text:
One of the unusual features of the Mn+1AXn phases (where M is a transition metal, A is a group A element, X is carbon or nitrogen, and n=1,2,3…) is that for a given M−A−X system, only certain values of n are found to occur and there is no systematic behavior between the different systems. Density-functional theory was used to verify the stability of the different phases by comparing their total energy to that of the appropriate competing phases. Five systems (Ti-Al-C, Ti-Si-C, Ti-Al-N, Ti-Si-N, and Cr-Al-C) were studied for n=1–4. Complete agreement with observed occurrences of these phases was found. Very small energy differences suggest that it may be possible to fabricate Ti2SiC, Ti2SiN, and Ti3AlN2 as metastable phases. None of the M5AX4 phases were predicted to occur and in all cases the α phases were found to be more energetically favorable than the β phases.

DOI:https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevB.80.214113
